data.title: LineEdit long indicator, fix #6624
data.body: Fixes too high caret and selection

data.title: "Condition ' !texture ' is true." error in RasterizerGLES2 when using sub viewports
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7 64bit - Godot v2.1-stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Adding a viewport as a child of control results in two errors:

> Time: 0:00:00:0538
> C Error: Condition ' !elem ' is true. returned: 0
> C Source: core\rid.h:146
> C Function: RID_Owner<struct RasterizerGLES2::Texture,0>::get

and

> Time: 0:00:00:0545
> C Error: Condition ' !texture ' is true.
> C Source: drivers\gles2\rasterizer_gles2.cpp:1280
> C Function: RasterizerGLES2::texture_set_flags 

Whatever is causing those errors, the subviewport seems to be working as intended.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create new project and scene
2. Add a Control node
3. Add a Viewport node as a child of that Control node
4. Save and play the scene

data.title: Don't crash when video is stopped and played again
data.body:
in GDscript stopping the video with sound and playing it again, e.g.:

```
stop()
play()
```

causes a crash in resampler. This patch fixes it - don't free arrays in resampler as in other `stream_player` classes.

data.title: Cannot automatically update mouse cursor shape or visibility
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Linux/X11 and Windows, Godot 2.1-stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Mouse cursor shape and visibility behaves differently in X11 and Windows - cannot automatically update cursor shape or visibility without user interaction.

**Steps to reproduce:**

X11:
- download `Mousetest` project and run, assume that mouse cursor is inside the window when it starts,
- the mouse cursor has busy icon, but it should automatically switch to pointer arrow (it does it after mouse move),
- place mouse cursor inside the window and wait 2 seconds; don't move the mouse cursor,
- mouse cursor disappears - OK,
- move mouse to show the cursor - the mouse cursor automatically changes its shape from Godot theme to system theme (sometimes it happens after second cursor visibility change). And why it doesn't have system theme on X11 as default?

Windows:
- download `Mousetest` project and run,
- place mouse cursor inside the window and wait 2 seconds; don't move the mouse cursor,
- mouse cursor doesn't disappear automatically, so you must click and don't move the mouse to achieve this (normally you can also move the mouse to hide the mouse cursor, but the script will show it).

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[Mousetest.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/497656/Mousetest.zip)

data.title: Y Sort not working with children of a child node
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot_v2.1-stable_win64.exe

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Create a tilemap, enable Y Sort.

Add child nodes to that tilemap. Y Sort works fine for all children. But when you add a child that has its own children, Y Sort doesn't work for them.  

Example:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10387670/18893071/22d0e9ea-84c1-11e6-8cb8-3f901d704a3a.png)

data.title: Godot editor spawning zombie processes
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**

debian 8 x64 ( stable )
godot 2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
On being instructed to use external editor, Godot spawns zombie processes of that editor and itself.

**Steps to reproduce:**

1) Set external editor in the Settings -> Editor Settings -> External editor ( click "On" and write the path to executable )

2) Open up 2-3 scenes with scripts so that external text editor will fire up showing .gd files

3) close external text editor

4) see zombie processes crawling around:

ps -A | grep defunct
     or
top

Tested and confirmed with geany and gvim. 
Observed 2-3 copies of zombie "Godot_v2.1-stab" process and a dozen of gvim or geany zombie instances.

data.title: Fix for crash when finding intersection on colliders that overlap
data.body: This is a fix for #6610. It seems the crash happens when there are more collision shapes than max_results specified to intersect_point. I made it so it ignores remaining results. Maybe it would be better to return the ones on top, but at least it doesn't crash anymore.

Explanation: Assertions.
Assertions are not checked at runtime. There are ways to request that they be used by Dalvik (adb shell setprop debug.assert 1), but the property is ignored in many places and can not be relied upon. Instead, perform conditional checking inside if (BuildConfig.DEBUG) { } blocks. That constant is a static final boolean which is true in debug builds and false in release builds, and the Java compiler completely removes all code inside the if-body from the app.

For example, you can replace assert speed > 0 with if (BuildConfig.DEBUG && !(speed > 0)) { throw new AssertionError() }.

(Note: This lint check does not flag assertions purely asserting nullness or non-nullness; these are typically more intended for tools usage than runtime checks.)

Category: Correctness
Severity: Warning
Explanation: Implied default locale in case conversion.
Calling String#toLowerCase() or #toUpperCase() without specifying an explicit locale is a common source of bugs. The reason for that is that those methods will use the current locale on the user's device, and even though the code appears to work correctly when you are developing the app, it will fail in some locales. For example, in the Turkish locale, the uppercase replacement for i is not I.

If you want the methods to just perform ASCII replacement, for example to convert an enum name, call String#toUpperCase(Locale.US) instead. If you really want to use the current locale, call String#toUpperCase(Locale.getDefault()) instead.

More info: http://developer.android.com/reference/java/util/Locale.html#default_locale

To suppress this error, use the issue id "DefaultLocale" as explained in the Suppressing Warnings and Errors section.

Priority: 6 / 10
Category: Correctness
Severity: Warning
Explanation: Using inlined constants on older versions.
This check scans through all the Android API field references in the application and flags certain constants, such as static final integers and Strings, which were introduced in later versions. These will actually be copied into the class files rather than being referenced, which means that the value is available even when running on older devices. In some cases that's fine, and in other cases it can result in a runtime crash or incorrect behavior. It depends on the context, so consider the code carefully and device whether it's safe and can be suppressed or whether the code needs tbe guarded.

If you really want to use this API and don't need to support older devices just set the minSdkVersion in your build.gradle or AndroidManifest.xml files.
If your code is deliberately accessing newer APIs, and you have ensured (e.g. with conditional execution) that this code will only ever be called on a supported platform, then you can annotate your class or method with the @TargetApi annotation specifying the local minimum SDK to apply, such as @TargetApi(11), such that this check considers 11 rather than your manifest file's minimum SDK as the required API level.

More info:

To suppress this error, use the issue id "InlinedApi" as explained in the Suppressing Warnings and Errors section.

Category: Security
Severity: Warning
Explanation: Weak RNG.
Key generation, signing, encryption, and random number generation may not receive cryptographically strong values due to improper initialization of the underlying PRNG on Android 4.3 and below.

If your application relies on cryptographically secure random number generation you should apply the workaround described in https://android-developers.blogspot.com/2013/08/some-securerandom-thoughts.html .

This lint rule is mostly informational; it does not accurately detect whether cryptographically secure RNG is required, or whether the workaround has already been applied. After reading the blog entry and updating your code if necessary, you can disable this lint issue.

More info: https://android-developers.blogspot.com/2013/08/some-securerandom-thoughts.html

Priority: 4 / 10
Category: Performance
Severity: Warning
Explanation: Handler reference leaks.
Since this Handler is declared as an inner class, it may prevent the outer class from being garbage collected. If the Handler is using a Looper or MessageQueue for a thread other than the main thread, then there is no issue. If the Handler is using the Looper or MessageQueue of the main thread, you need to fix your Handler declaration, as follows: Declare the Handler as a static class; In the outer class, instantiate a WeakReference to the outer class and pass this object to your Handler when you instantiate the Handler; Make all references to members of the outer class using the WeakReference object.

More info:

To suppress this error, use the issue id "HandlerLeak" as explained in the Suppressing Warnings and Errors section.

Priority: 4 / 10
Category: Performance

Explanation: HashMap can be replaced with SparseArray.
For maps where the keys are of type integer, it's typically more efficient to use the Android SparseArray API. This check identifies scenarios where you might want to consider using SparseArray instead of HashMap for better performance.

This is particularly useful when the value types are primitives like ints, where you can use SparseIntArray and avoid auto-boxing the values from int to Integer.

If you need to construct a HashMap because you need to call an API outside of your control which requires a Map, you can suppress this warning using for example the @SuppressLint annotation.

                  Using Gravity#LEFT and Gravity#RIGHT can lead to problems when a layout is rendered in locales where text flows from right to left. Use Gravity#START and Gravity#END instead. Similarly, in XML gravity and layout_gravity attributes, use start rather than left.

                  For XML attributes such as paddingLeft and layout_marginLeft, use paddingStart and layout_marginStart. NOTE: If your minSdkVersion is less than 17, you should add both the older left/right attributes as well as the new start/right attributes. On older platforms, where RTL is not supported and the start/right attributes are unknown and therefore ignored, you need the older left/right attributes. There is a separate lint check which catches that type of error.

                  (Note: For Gravity#LEFT and Gravity#START, you can use these constants even when targeting older platforms, because the start bitmask is a superset of the left bitmask. Therefore, you can use gravity="start" rather than gravity="left|start".)

                  This check is not very sophisticated (it just looks for buttons with the label "Back"), so it is disabled by default to not trigger on common scenarios like pairs of Back/Next buttons to paginate through screens.

                  Suppressing Warnings and Errors
                  Lint errors can be suppressed in a variety of ways:

                  1. With a @SuppressLint annotation in the Java code
                  2. With a tools:ignore attribute in the XML file
                  3. With ignore flags specified in the build.gradle file, as explained below
                  4. With a lint.xml configuration file in the project
                  5. With a lint.xml configuration file passed to lint via the --config flag
                  6. With the --ignore flag passed to lint.

                  To suppress a lint warning with an annotation, add a @SuppressLint("id") annotation on the class, method or variable declaration closest to the warning instance you want to disable. The id can be one or more issue id's, such as "UnusedResources" or {"UnusedResources","UnusedIds"}, or it can be "all" to suppress all lint warnings in the given scope.

                  To suppress a lint warning in an XML file, add a tools:ignore="id" attribute on the element containing the error, or one of its surrounding elements. You also need to define the namespace for the tools prefix on the root element in your document, next to the xmlns:android declaration:
                  xmlns:tools="http://schemas.android.com/tools"

                  To suppress a lint warning in a build.gradle file, add a section like this:

                  android {
                      lintOptions {
                          disable 'TypographyFractions','TypographyQuotes'
                      }
                  }

                  Here we specify a comma separated list of issue id's after the disable command. You can also use warning or error instead of disable to change the severity of issues.

                  To suppress lint warnings with a configuration XML file, create a file named lint.xml and place it at the root directory of the project in which it applies.

                  The format of the lint.xml file is something like the following:

                  <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
                  <lint>
                      <!-- Disable this given check in this project -->
                      <issue id="IconMissingDensityFolder" severity="ignore" />

                      <!-- Ignore the ObsoleteLayoutParam issue in the given files -->
                      <issue id="ObsoleteLayoutParam">
                          <ignore path="res/layout/activation.xml" />
                          <ignore path="res/layout-xlarge/activation.xml" />
                      </issue>

                      <!-- Ignore the UselessLeaf issue in the given file -->
                      <issue id="UselessLeaf">
                          <ignore path="res/layout/main.xml" />
                      </issue>

                      <!-- Change the severity of hardcoded strings to "error" -->
                      <issue id="HardcodedText" severity="error" />
                  </lint>

                  To suppress lint checks from the command line, pass the --ignore flag with a comma separated list of ids to be suppressed, such as:
                  $ lint --ignore UnusedResources,UselessLeaf /my/project/path

                  For more information, see http://g.co/androidstudio/suppressing-lint-warnings

Now these methods show the list of available actions during a completion request.
Fixes #6621

data.title: not implementing one of the functions when using selfget should throw an error
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
v2.1.stable.official

When using `setget` but not implementing one of the two functions:

``` python
var a setget ,get_a
# or
var a setget set_a
```

and accessing the unimplemented part Godot should throw an error, for example in the first case doing `self.a = 'something'`, the same for the second: `print(self.a)` should throw an error. At the moment, in the first case nothing happens and in the second case `self.a` returns `null`. I can't remember how Python behaves when using the `@property` decorator but I think it throws an error when used improperly.

data.title: is_action_just_pressed() and is_action_just_released() do not list available actions
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7
Godot 2.2 compiled from source on 15/09/2016

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Both Input functions is_action_just_pressed() and is_action_just_released() fail to list available actions when the first open bracket is typed. Other Input functions like is_action_pressed() correctly list the available actions.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Type the following into the editor:
"Input.is_action_just_pressed(" - no list will be shown
"Input.is_action_pressed(" - a list will appear

data.title: Captured mouse causes get_local_mouse_pos() to return crazy Y values

Windows 7

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
When setting Input.set_mouse_mode() to MOUSE_MODE_CAPTURED, any calls to get_local_mouse_pos() or get_global_mouse_pos() returns values like the examples below:

(-160, 1068756672)
(-159.5, 534378304)
(-194.5, 534378400)

**Steps to reproduce:**
Run the project attached and see the printed output. ESC will close the example since the mouse is captured.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3292249/mouse_capture.zip

data.title: PopupMenu items can't use customizable shortcuts.
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
You can add items to a `PopupMenu` with an optional shortcut, using e.g.: 
`add_item("name", id, KEY_MASK_CMD|KEY_A)`

 However the shortcut is hardcoded and it won't accept the new customizable shortcuts (`ED_GET_SHORTCUT`).
One use-case would be the context menu for the script editor.

data.title: Scene import - specify user clips in frames, not seconds
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
win godot 2.1

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
I downloaded this model:
https://shop.bitgem3d.com/collections/free-3d-models/products/low-poly-zombie-commoner

Imported "fbx" it in a blender and exported in the "DAE" (using the standard export and also via "godotengine/collada-exporter")

I created a new project and tried to import the "dae" in it. just before you set up the import tab "Animation Options: Clips"
The animation is not broken up into clips. All clips appear in the player but were empty.

**Steps to reproduce:**

1 select inport
2 select dae file
3 add user clips in "Animation Options: Clips"
4 import and open
5 test user animation clips

data.title: Fixes in Theora SCsub
data.body:
- properly pass x86 assembly define to the compiler,
- don't compile unnecessary/encoder files.

data.title: Use libyuv library for YUV->RGB conversion
data.body:
Add only necessary files and SCsub file. Remove `yuv2rgb.h` and use `libyuv` in Theora.

This improves performance and will be also used in the WebM driver.

data.title: Make FileDialog directory selection less misleading
data.body:
This should fix #5989.

Changes which applied to FileDialog and EditorFileDialog are basically the same:
- show `.(current working directory)` in Tree/ItemList
- append name of selected item with current directory when under MODE_OPEN_DIR

Here's some screenshots:

data.title: Tween reset/stop/resume/remove for all object properties at once
data.body:
It would be easier to stop or resume tween for all object properties at once with one line of code.
Now it needs to be done one by one or with a loop.
My proposal is to pass an empty String to impact all tweens for a given object.
I've set the property param as default so syntax is more compact:
`get_node("Tween").reset(get_node("Node"))`
It will reset all tweens for Node.

data.title: Selecting NodePath does not work on nested exported array
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 7/Ubuntu 16.04 64bit - Godot v2.2alpha.custom.build (fixnum - 09/22)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
In the inspector, selecting a node for NodePath type array value if the array is part of another array, the selected path shows a bad value (points to EditorNode)

What was supposed to happen is getting the path to the selected node on the scene tree.

Capture of the path just selected on the second Array:

![badnodepath](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10215987/18817047/b6d90014-832c-11e6-916b-30431dc9b961.png)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1- Make a node with a script
2- Add `export(Array) var variable_name` to the script
3- On the Inspector, edit the exported array and add an element of type Array
4- Edit the new array and add an element of type NodePath
5- Select a node and you will get a bad path value

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
Project with a single node and the bad path already selected on the nested array.
[badnodepath.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/491787/badnodepath.zip)

data.title: Don't crash in "_process_hdr()" if "framebuffer.luminance" is empty
data.body:
If "glFramebufferTexture2D()" fails on old drivers the Vector is empty.
Don't allow to read from empty Vector (NULL pointer).
